canonical_explanation.text: Biological classification is the process of grouping organisms based on shared characteristics. R.H. Whittaker (1969) proposed the five-kingdom classification system based on cell structure, body organisation, mode of nutrition, reproduction, and phylogenetic relationships. The five kingdoms are Monera (prokaryotes), Protista (unicellular eukaryotes), Fungi (heterotrophic eukaryotes with cell walls of chitin), Plantae (multicellular autotrophs), and Animalia (multicellular heterotrophs without cell walls). Kingdom Monera includes all prokaryotic organisms and is divided into Archaebacteria and Eubacteria. Archaebacteria are ancient bacteria that live in extreme environments such as hot springs (thermoacidophiles), salt lakes (halophiles), and marshy areas (methanogens). Eubacteria include most common bacteria, which may be autotrophic (photosynthetic like cyanobacteria, or chemosynthetic) or heterotrophic. Bacteria have four shapes: coccus (spherical), bacillus (rod), vibrio (comma), and spirillum (spiral). They reproduce mainly by binary fission and sometimes show genetic recombination. Kingdom Protista includes unicellular eukaryotes such as Chrysophytes (diatoms and golden algae), Dinoflagellates, Euglenoids, Slime moulds, and Protozoans. Kingdom Fungi are heterotrophic organisms that obtain nutrition by absorption. They include Phycomycetes (e.g., Mucor, Rhizopus), Ascomycetes (sac fungi, e.g., Aspergillus, yeast), Basidiomycetes (club fungi, e.g., mushrooms, puffballs), and Deuteromycetes (imperfect fungi). Viruses are non-cellular infectious agents with either DNA or RNA enclosed in a protein coat (capsid). They are obligate intracellular parasites that reproduce only inside host cells. Viroids are smaller than viruses, consisting of free RNA without a protein coat, and cause plant diseases. Prions are infectious protein particles that cause neurological diseases like mad cow disease. Lichens are symbiotic associations between algae (phycobiont) and fungi (mycobiont).
rules: Whittaker's five kingdoms: Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, Animalia — based on cell structure, nutrition, body organisation, reproduction, and phylogeny.
Monera = prokaryotes; Archaebacteria (extremophiles) and Eubacteria (common bacteria including cyanobacteria).
Bacterial shapes: coccus (sphere), bacillus (rod), vibrio (comma), spirillum (spiral).
Protista includes Chrysophytes, Dinoflagellates, Euglenoids, Slime moulds, and Protozoans — all unicellular eukaryotes.
Fungi have chitin cell walls, are heterotrophic by absorption; classes include Phycomycetes, Ascomycetes, Basidiomycetes, Deuteromycetes.
Ascomycetes produce ascospores in asci; Basidiomycetes produce basidiospores on basidia.
Viruses are acellular, obligate parasites with DNA or RNA in a protein capsid; discovered by Ivanowsky (TMV).
Viroids are free RNA molecules (no protein coat) causing plant diseases; discovered by T.O. Diener.
Prions are infectious proteins causing neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., mad cow disease/BSE).
Lichens are symbiotic associations between algae (phycobiont) and fungi (mycobiont); they are pollution indicators.

questions.question_text: The five-kingdom classification was proposed by:
questions.explanation_correct: R.H. Whittaker proposed the five-kingdom classification in 1969, dividing all organisms into Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia based on cell structure, body organisation, mode of nutrition, reproduction, and phylogenetic relationships.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Linnaeus proposed the two-kingdom system, Haeckel proposed the three-kingdom system, and Woese proposed the three-domain system. Whittaker introduced the five-kingdom classification.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a criterion used by Whittaker for his five-kingdom classification?
questions.explanation_correct: Whittaker used five main criteria: cell structure, body organisation, mode of nutrition, mode of reproduction, and phylogenetic relationships. Habitat type was not among his classification criteria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell structure, mode of nutrition, and body organisation are all valid Whittaker criteria. Habitat type (aquatic, terrestrial, etc.) was not used as a basis for his five-kingdom classification.

questions.question_text: An organism is unicellular, eukaryotic, and primarily autotrophic. In Whittaker's classification, it would be placed in kingdom:
questions.explanation_correct: Unicellular eukaryotes, regardless of their mode of nutrition, are placed in kingdom Protista in Whittaker's classification. This includes autotrophic forms like diatoms and euglenoids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monera is for prokaryotes. Plantae includes multicellular autotrophs. Fungi are heterotrophic. Unicellular eukaryotes, whether autotrophic or heterotrophic, are classified under Protista.

questions.question_text: Which kingdom was separated from Plantae by Whittaker due to differences in cell wall composition and mode of nutrition?
questions.explanation_correct: Whittaker separated Fungi from Plantae because fungi have cell walls made of chitin (not cellulose), are heterotrophic by absorption (not autotrophic), and have a fundamentally different nutritional strategy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monera was separated based on being prokaryotic. Protista was for unicellular eukaryotes. Animalia lacked cell walls entirely. Fungi were specifically separated from Plantae due to chitin cell walls and absorptive heterotrophic nutrition.

questions.question_text: Archaebacteria differ from Eubacteria primarily in:

options.text: Having a different cell wall structure and ability to survive extreme conditions

questions.explanation_correct: Archaebacteria have a different cell wall structure (lacking peptidoglycan in many cases) compared to Eubacteria. They are adapted to survive in extreme environments such as hot springs, salt lakes, and marshy areas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both Archaebacteria and Eubacteria are prokaryotes (no membrane-bound nucleus), typically unicellular, and lack chloroplasts. Their key differences lie in cell wall composition and their ability to thrive in extreme habitats.

questions.question_text: Methanogens are a type of Archaebacteria found in:

options.text: The gut of ruminant animals like cattle

questions.explanation_correct: Methanogens are Archaebacteria that produce methane gas. They are found in marshy areas and in the gut of ruminant animals such as cattle, where they help in cellulose digestion and produce biogas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While methanogens can be found in various anaerobic environments, they are characteristically present in the gut of ruminant animals and marshy areas. They are not found in the atmosphere or specifically in freshwater ponds.

questions.question_text: Cyanobacteria are placed in kingdom Monera because they:

options.text: Have chitin in their cell walls

questions.explanation_correct: Cyanobacteria (blue-green algae) are prokaryotic organisms. Despite being photosynthetic and sometimes forming filamentous colonies, they lack a membrane-bound nucleus and are classified under kingdom Monera.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cyanobacteria are autotrophic (not heterotrophic), do not have chitin cell walls (that is fungi), and are prokaryotic (not eukaryotic). Their prokaryotic nature places them in Monera.

questions.question_text: The four basic shapes of bacteria are coccus, bacillus, vibrio, and spirillum. Which shape is described as comma-shaped?
questions.explanation_correct: Vibrio bacteria are comma-shaped (e.g., Vibrio cholerae, which causes cholera). Coccus is spherical, bacillus is rod-shaped, and spirillum is spiral-shaped.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coccus = spherical, bacillus = rod-shaped, spirillum = spiral/helical. Vibrio is the comma-shaped form, exemplified by the cholera-causing bacterium Vibrio cholerae.

questions.question_text: A bacterium obtains energy by oxidising inorganic chemicals like ammonia to nitrates. This mode of nutrition is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Chemoautotrophic bacteria synthesise their food using energy from chemical reactions involving inorganic substances. Nitrifying bacteria like Nitrosomonas oxidise ammonia to nitrites, and Nitrobacter oxidises nitrites to nitrates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Photoautotrophs use light energy. Saprophytes feed on dead organic matter. Parasites feed on living hosts. Bacteria that oxidise inorganic chemicals for energy are chemoautotrophs.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Cyanobacteria are also known as blue-green algae.
Reason (R): Cyanobacteria contain chlorophyll a and are photosynthetic prokaryotes.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Cyanobacteria are called blue-green algae because they are photosynthetic (containing chlorophyll a) and have a blue-green colour due to the pigment phycocyanin. The reason correctly explains why they resemble algae and are called so.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true (cyanobacteria are indeed called blue-green algae), and the reason is true (they do contain chlorophyll a and are photosynthetic prokaryotes). The reason explains the assertion because their photosynthetic ability is why they were historically called algae.

questions.question_text: The most common mode of reproduction in bacteria is:
questions.explanation_correct: Binary fission is the most common mode of reproduction in bacteria. The bacterial cell replicates its DNA and divides into two identical daughter cells. This is an asexual process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While bacteria can exchange genetic material through conjugation, transformation, or transduction, these are not true sexual reproduction. Budding occurs in some organisms like yeast. Binary fission is the primary reproductive method in bacteria.

questions.question_text: Halophiles, thermoacidophiles, and methanogens are all examples of:
questions.explanation_correct: Halophiles (salt-loving), thermoacidophiles (heat and acid-loving), and methanogens (methane-producing) are all types of Archaebacteria. These organisms thrive in extreme environments and represent some of the most ancient life forms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: These extremophile organisms are not Eubacteria (common bacteria), Protista (unicellular eukaryotes), or Fungi. They are classified as Archaebacteria due to their unique cell wall structure and ability to survive in extreme conditions.

questions.question_text: Diatoms belong to which group in kingdom Protista?
questions.explanation_correct: Diatoms belong to the Chrysophytes (golden algae and diatoms). They are characterised by siliceous cell walls (frustules) that fit together like a soap box, and they are important primary producers in aquatic ecosystems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dinoflagellates have cellulose plates, euglenoids have flexible pellicle, and slime moulds form plasmodium. Diatoms are classified under Chrysophytes due to their golden-brown colour and siliceous cell walls.

questions.question_text: The cell walls of diatoms are made of silica and are indestructible. This property has led to the formation of:

options.text: Diatomaceous earth, used in polishing and filtration

questions.explanation_correct: The indestructible siliceous cell walls of diatoms accumulate over millions of years to form diatomaceous earth. This substance is used in polishing, filtration of oils and syrups, and as an insulating material.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Limestone and chalk are calcium carbonate deposits (from foraminifera). Petroleum has multiple organic sources. Diatomaceous earth specifically forms from accumulated siliceous diatom frustules.

questions.question_text: Red tides in the sea are caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Red tides are caused by rapid multiplication (blooms) of dinoflagellates such as Gonyaulax. Their red pigments colour the sea water, and the toxins they release can kill marine organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chrysophytes, euglenoids, and slime moulds do not cause red tides. Dinoflagellates like Gonyaulax are responsible for red tides due to their explosive population growth and release of toxins.

questions.question_text: Euglena is unique among protists because it:

options.text: Has a rigid cellulose cell wall
Is photosynthetic in light but heterotrophic in darkness (mixotrophic)

questions.explanation_correct: Euglenoids like Euglena are mixotrophic: they are photosynthetic when light is available (having chloroplasts) but become heterotrophic in the dark. They have a flexible protein-rich layer called pellicle instead of a cell wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Euglenoids lack a cellulose cell wall (they have a pellicle), reproduce asexually by longitudinal binary fission, and are unicellular (not colonial). Their defining feature is mixotrophic nutrition.

questions.question_text: The cell wall of fungi is composed of:
questions.explanation_correct: The cell wall of fungi is composed of chitin, a complex polysaccharide made of N-acetylglucosamine units. This distinguishes fungi from plants (cellulose walls) and bacteria (peptidoglycan walls).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cellulose is found in plant cell walls, peptidoglycan in bacterial cell walls, and silica in diatom frustules. Chitin is the characteristic cell wall component of fungi.

questions.question_text: Fungi that produce sexual spores called ascospores are classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Ascomycetes (sac fungi) produce sexual spores called ascospores inside a sac-like structure called an ascus. Examples include Aspergillus, Penicillium, Neurospora, and yeasts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phycomycetes produce zoospores and zygospores. Basidiomycetes produce basidiospores. Deuteromycetes lack known sexual stages. Only Ascomycetes produce ascospores in asci.

questions.question_text: Mushrooms, bracket fungi, and puffballs are all examples of:
questions.explanation_correct: Mushrooms, bracket fungi, and puffballs are all Basidiomycetes (club fungi). They produce sexual spores called basidiospores on club-shaped structures called basidia, typically found on the gills of mushrooms or within the fruiting body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phycomycetes include bread mould (Mucor, Rhizopus). Ascomycetes include Aspergillus and yeast. Deuteromycetes are imperfect fungi. Mushrooms, bracket fungi, and puffballs are classic examples of Basidiomycetes.

questions.question_text: Deuteromycetes are called 'imperfect fungi' because:

options.text: Their sexual reproduction stage (perfect stage) has not been observed

questions.explanation_correct: Deuteromycetes are termed 'imperfect fungi' because only their asexual (imperfect) stage of reproduction is known. The sexual (perfect) stage has either not been observed or does not exist.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Deuteromycetes do have cell walls (of chitin), can produce asexual spores (conidia), and can be saprophytic or parasitic. The term 'imperfect' refers specifically to the absence of a known sexual reproductive stage.

questions.question_text: Slime moulds are unusual protists because during their life cycle they:

options.text: Form an aggregation called plasmodium that can move and engulf food
Have rigid cellulose cell walls at all stages

questions.explanation_correct: Slime moulds form an aggregation of cells that creates a multinucleate mass called plasmodium. This plasmodium can move on decaying matter and engulf organic debris like an amoeba, showing both fungal and animal-like properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Slime moulds have both unicellular and multicellular phases. They form spores with cell walls under unfavourable conditions but lack rigid walls during the plasmodial phase. They are saprophytic, not parasitic.

questions.question_text: Protozoans are classified into groups based on their:
questions.explanation_correct: Protozoans are classified based on their locomotory structures: Amoeboid protozoans (pseudopodia), Flagellated protozoans (flagella), Ciliated protozoans (cilia), and Sporozoans (no locomotory organs).
questions.explanation_incorrect: While nutrition, reproduction, and habitat may vary, the primary basis for classifying protozoans into groups is their type of locomotory structures (pseudopodia, flagella, cilia, or none).

questions.question_text: Plasmodium, the malaria-causing parasite, is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Plasmodium is a sporozoan (Apicomplexa). Sporozoans lack specific locomotory structures and are obligate parasites. They have a spore-like infective stage in their complex life cycle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plasmodium does not use flagella, cilia, or pseudopodia for movement. It is a sporozoan, characterised by the absence of locomotory structures and an obligate parasitic lifestyle.

questions.question_text: Tobacco Mosaic Virus (TMV) was discovered by:
questions.explanation_correct: D.J. Ivanowsky (1892) discovered that the causal agent of tobacco mosaic disease was smaller than bacteria and could pass through bacterial filters. This agent was later named Tobacco Mosaic Virus (TMV) by M.W. Beijerinck.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pasteur developed germ theory and vaccines, Jenner developed the smallpox vaccine, and Koch identified bacterial pathogens. Ivanowsky discovered the filterable infectious agent of tobacco mosaic disease, later identified as TMV.

questions.question_text: Viruses are considered to be on the borderline of living and non-living because they:

options.text: Can reproduce independently without a host
Are crystallisable outside a host but show living characteristics inside a host cell
Have a well-defined cell membrane and organelles

questions.explanation_correct: Viruses can be crystallised like non-living chemicals outside a host, but inside a living cell, they take over the host machinery to replicate and show characteristics of life. This dual nature places them on the borderline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Viruses cannot reproduce independently (they need a host), are acellular (not multicellular), and lack cell membranes and organelles. Their ability to crystallise yet replicate inside hosts makes them borderline living/non-living.

questions.question_text: A virus that infects bacteria is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A bacteriophage (literally 'bacteria eater') is a virus that specifically infects and replicates within bacterial cells. Well-known examples include the T-phages that infect E. coli.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Viroids are free RNA molecules infecting plants. Prions are infectious proteins. Mycoplasma are the smallest known bacteria. Only bacteriophages are viruses that specifically infect bacteria.

questions.question_text: Viroids differ from viruses in that viroids:

options.text: Have a protein coat surrounding their nucleic acid
Consist of free RNA without a protein coat
Can reproduce outside a host cell

questions.explanation_correct: Viroids are smaller than viruses and consist of short, circular, single-stranded RNA molecules without any protein coat. They were discovered by T.O. Diener in 1971 and primarily cause plant diseases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Viroids lack a protein coat (unlike viruses), contain only RNA (not both DNA and RNA), and are obligate parasites that cannot reproduce outside host cells. Their defining feature is being free RNA without a capsid.

questions.question_text: Mad cow disease (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy) is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Mad cow disease (BSE) is caused by prions, which are misfolded infectious protein particles. Prions lack nucleic acid entirely and cause neurodegenerative diseases by inducing normal proteins to misfold.
questions.explanation_incorrect: BSE is not caused by a virus, bacterium, or viroid. It is caused by prions, which are infectious proteins that lack nucleic acid and cause fatal neurodegenerative diseases.

questions.question_text: In a lichen, the algal partner is called phycobiont and the fungal partner is called mycobiont. The relationship between them is:

options.text: Parasitism, where the fungus exploits the alga
Commensalism, where only one partner benefits
Mutualistic symbiosis, where both partners benefit
Competition, where both compete for nutrients

questions.explanation_correct: Lichens represent a mutualistic symbiotic association. The algal component (phycobiont) provides food through photosynthesis, while the fungal component (mycobiont) provides shelter, absorbs water and minerals, and creates a protective environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lichen relationship is not parasitic (both benefit), not commensal (both gain), and not competitive (they cooperate). It is a classic example of mutualistic symbiosis.

questions.question_text: Lichens are considered good indicators of:
questions.explanation_correct: Lichens are highly sensitive to sulphur dioxide (SO₂) and other air pollutants. They do not grow in polluted areas, making them excellent bioindicators of air quality. Their absence from an area suggests high pollution levels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While lichens may be affected by various environmental factors, they are specifically recognised as indicators of air pollution, particularly SO₂ levels. They are not standard indicators of water quality, soil fertility, or temperature.

questions.question_text: In the two-kingdom classification by Linnaeus, fungi were placed in kingdom Plantae. Whittaker separated them into a separate kingdom based on which key difference?

options.text: Fungi are heterotrophic and have chitin cell walls

questions.explanation_correct: Whittaker separated fungi from plants because fungi are heterotrophic (absorptive nutrition) unlike autotrophic plants, and their cell walls contain chitin rather than cellulose. These fundamental differences justified a separate kingdom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Most fungi are non-motile. Many fungi are multicellular (except yeasts). Fungi reproduce both sexually and asexually. The key reasons for separation were heterotrophic nutrition and chitin cell walls.

questions.question_text: Which of the following bacteria are helpful in nitrogen fixation in leguminous plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Rhizobium is a nitrogen-fixing bacterium that forms a symbiotic association with the roots of leguminous plants. It lives in root nodules and converts atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, which the plant can use.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, Clostridium tetani causes tetanus, and Staphylococcus aureus causes skin infections. Rhizobium is the nitrogen-fixing symbiont of legumes.

questions.question_text: Mycoplasma are the smallest known living organisms. They differ from other bacteria in that they:
questions.explanation_correct: Mycoplasma are the smallest known living cells and are unique among bacteria in completely lacking a cell wall. They are pleomorphic (can assume various shapes) and are pathogenic in both animals and plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mycoplasma are prokaryotic (no nucleus), not eukaryotic, and are heterotrophic (many are parasites). Their distinguishing feature is the complete absence of a cell wall.

questions.question_text: Bread mould (Rhizopus) belongs to which class of fungi?
questions.explanation_correct: Rhizopus (bread mould) belongs to Phycomycetes (also called Zygomycetes by some authors). Phycomycetes are characterised by aseptate (coenocytic) mycelium and production of zoospores and zygospores.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ascomycetes produce ascospores (e.g., Aspergillus), Basidiomycetes produce basidiospores (e.g., mushrooms), and Deuteromycetes lack known sexual stages. Rhizopus is a classic Phycomycete.

questions.question_text:
Match the following:
(i) Penicillium — (a) Basidiomycetes
(ii) Agaricus — (b) Phycomycetes
(iii) Mucor — (c) Deuteromycetes
(iv) Alternaria — (d) Ascomycetes

Select the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Penicillium is an Ascomycete (d), Agaricus (mushroom) is a Basidiomycete (a), Mucor is a Phycomycete (b), and Alternaria is a Deuteromycete/imperfect fungus (c).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct classification is: Penicillium (Ascomycetes, produces ascospores), Agaricus (Basidiomycetes, produces basidiospores on mushroom gills), Mucor (Phycomycetes, coenocytic mycelium), Alternaria (Deuteromycetes, no known sexual stage).

questions.question_text: Yeast is a unicellular fungus that reproduces asexually by:
questions.explanation_correct: Yeast (Saccharomyces) is a unicellular ascomycete that reproduces asexually by budding. A small outgrowth (bud) develops on the parent cell, enlarges, and eventually separates to form a new individual.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Binary fission is typical of bacteria. Fragmentation occurs in filamentous organisms. Zoospore formation occurs in some Phycomycetes. Yeast characteristically reproduces asexually by budding.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Virus is not placed in any of the five kingdoms.
Reason (R): Viruses are acellular and do not exhibit all characteristics of living organisms.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Viruses are not placed in any of the five kingdoms because they are acellular, lack cellular organisation, and do not show all characteristics of living organisms (e.g., they cannot metabolise or reproduce independently). The reason correctly explains the assertion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Viruses are indeed excluded from the five-kingdom system because they are acellular and lack independent life processes. The reason directly explains why they are excluded from classification.

questions.question_text: The protein coat of a virus is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The protein coat that surrounds the nucleic acid of a virus is called a capsid. It is made up of protein subunits called capsomeres. The capsid protects the genetic material and helps in attachment to host cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pellicle is the outer covering of euglenoids. Glycocalyx is found on bacterial surfaces. Tegument is a specialised layer in some complex viruses. The protein coat is universally called the capsid.

questions.question_text: Viroids were discovered by:
questions.explanation_correct: T.O. Diener (1971) discovered viroids while studying the potato spindle tuber disease. He found that the infectious agent was free RNA without any protein coat, smaller than any known virus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ivanowsky discovered the tobacco mosaic disease agent (virus). Stanley crystallised TMV. Beijerinck coined the term 'virus'. Diener discovered viroids as a new class of pathogens in 1971.

questions.question_text: Cyanobacteria can fix atmospheric nitrogen because they possess:
questions.explanation_correct: Many cyanobacteria (e.g., Nostoc, Anabaena) possess specialised thick-walled cells called heterocysts that provide an anaerobic environment for the enzyme nitrogenase to fix atmospheric nitrogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Root nodules are in legumes (not cyanobacteria). Cyanobacteria are prokaryotes and lack mitochondria and chloroplasts. Heterocysts are the specialised nitrogen-fixing cells unique to certain cyanobacteria.

questions.question_text: A fungus with septate mycelium, producing conidia as asexual spores and ascospores in asci as sexual spores, belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: The combination of septate mycelium, conidia (asexual), and ascospores in asci (sexual) is characteristic of Ascomycetes (sac fungi). Phycomycetes have aseptate mycelium, Basidiomycetes produce basidiospores, and Deuteromycetes lack sexual stages.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phycomycetes have aseptate (coenocytic) mycelium. Basidiomycetes produce basidiospores (not ascospores). Deuteromycetes lack known sexual stages. The described fungus with septate mycelium, conidia, and ascospores is an Ascomycete.

questions.question_text: Which kingdom in Whittaker's classification includes both autotrophic and heterotrophic organisms?
questions.explanation_correct: Kingdom Monera includes both autotrophic organisms (photoautotrophic cyanobacteria, chemoautotrophic bacteria) and heterotrophic organisms (saprophytic and parasitic bacteria). No other kingdom has such diverse nutritional modes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plantae are autotrophic, Fungi are heterotrophic, and Animalia are heterotrophic. Kingdom Monera uniquely includes both autotrophic (e.g., cyanobacteria) and heterotrophic (e.g., pathogenic bacteria) organisms.

questions.question_text: Dinoflagellates are characterised by:

options.text: Siliceous cell walls and being the chief producers in oceans
Two flagella, cellulose plates in cell wall, and some being bioluminescent
A flexible pellicle and mixotrophic nutrition
Pseudopodia for locomotion and phagocytic nutrition

questions.explanation_correct: Dinoflagellates are characterised by having two flagella (one longitudinal, one transverse), cell walls with stiff cellulose plates, and some species exhibit bioluminescence (e.g., Noctiluca). Some produce neurotoxins causing red tides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Siliceous cell walls describe diatoms. A flexible pellicle describes euglenoids. Pseudopodia describe amoeboid protozoans. Dinoflagellates specifically have two flagella and cellulose plate armour.

questions.question_text: A virus contains RNA as its genetic material and infects tobacco plants, causing mosaic-like patterns on leaves. This virus is:
questions.explanation_correct: Tobacco Mosaic Virus (TMV) is an RNA virus that infects tobacco plants, causing characteristic mosaic patterns (light and dark patches) on the leaves. It was the first virus to be discovered and crystallised.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bacteriophage T4 infects bacteria (DNA virus). HIV infects human immune cells. Influenza virus infects animals. TMV is the RNA virus that specifically infects tobacco plants causing mosaic patterns.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about bacteria is INCORRECT?

options.text: Bacteria have a rigid cell wall made of peptidoglycan
All bacteria are harmful and cause diseases
Bacteria reproduce mainly by binary fission

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that all bacteria are harmful is incorrect. Many bacteria are beneficial — they decompose organic matter, fix nitrogen, produce antibiotics, ferment foods, and are part of the normal human microbiome.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Most bacteria do have peptidoglycan cell walls (A is correct), they reproduce by binary fission (C is correct), and some are autotrophic like cyanobacteria (D is correct). Not all bacteria are harmful; many are beneficial.

questions.question_text: The body of a fungus is composed of thread-like structures called:
questions.explanation_correct: The body of a fungus is composed of long, thread-like structures called hyphae. The network of hyphae is collectively called a mycelium. Hyphae may be septate (divided into cells) or aseptate (coenocytic).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rhizoids are root-like structures for attachment. Flagella and cilia are locomotory structures. The thread-like filaments forming the fungal body are called hyphae.

questions.question_text: An organism is multicellular, eukaryotic, and obtains food by ingestion. According to Whittaker's classification, it belongs to kingdom:
questions.explanation_correct: Kingdom Animalia includes multicellular eukaryotic organisms that are heterotrophic and obtain nutrition by ingestion (holozoic nutrition). They lack cell walls and have well-developed organ systems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monera are prokaryotic. Protista are unicellular eukaryotes. Fungi obtain food by absorption, not ingestion. Multicellular eukaryotes with ingestive nutrition belong to Animalia.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly distinguishes prions from viruses?

options.text: Prions contain RNA but viruses contain DNA only
Prions are infectious proteins lacking nucleic acid, while viruses contain nucleic acid
Prions can reproduce independently but viruses cannot

questions.explanation_correct: The key distinction is that prions are infectious protein particles that completely lack nucleic acid (DNA or RNA), while viruses always contain either DNA or RNA as their genetic material enclosed in a protein capsid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Prions lack all nucleic acid (not just DNA). Prions are generally smaller than viruses, not larger. Neither prions nor viruses can reproduce independently. The absence of nucleic acid is the defining difference.

questions.question_text: Paramecium belongs to which group of protozoans?
questions.explanation_correct: Paramecium is a ciliated protozoan. Its entire body surface is covered with thousands of cilia, which are used for locomotion and feeding. It is a free-living organism found in freshwater habitats.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amoeboid protozoans use pseudopodia (e.g., Amoeba). Flagellated protozoans use flagella (e.g., Trypanosoma). Sporozoans lack locomotory structures (e.g., Plasmodium). Paramecium uses cilia and is classified as a ciliated protozoan.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about lichens is CORRECT?

options.text: The fungal partner performs photosynthesis while the algal partner provides shelter
Lichens grow rapidly in areas with high SO₂ pollution
Lichens are pioneer colonisers of bare rocks
The algal component in lichens is always a green alga

questions.explanation_correct: Lichens are pioneer species that can colonise bare rocks and other inhospitable surfaces. They secrete acids that break down the rock surface, contributing to soil formation. This makes them important in ecological succession.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In lichens, the algal partner photosynthesises (not the fungus). Lichens are sensitive to pollution and absent in polluted areas. The algal component can be a green alga or a cyanobacterium. Lichens being pioneer colonisers of bare rocks is correct.
